In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Certainly! Below is a Julia function `wrap_string` that iterates over words in a given string and inserts a newline character each time the maximum `text_width` would be exceeded. By default, the `text_width` is set to 10.

```julia
function wrap_string(input_string::String; text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(input_string)
    wrapped_lines = []
    current_line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            push!(wrapped_lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        else
            if isempty(current_line)
                current_line = word
            else
                current_line *= " " * word
            end
        end
    end

    if !isempty(current_line)
        push!(wrapped_lines, current_line)
    end

    return join(wrapped_lines, "\n")
end

# Example usage
input_string = "This is an example string that we want to wrap based on a specified text width."
wrapped_string = wrap_string(input_string, text_width=10)
println(wrapped_string)
```

```
example
string that
we want to
wrap based
on a
specified
text width.
```

In this example, the function `wrap_string` takes an input string and an optional `text_width` parameter (defaulting to 10). It splits the input string into words, iterates over them, and constructs lines that do not exceed the specified `text_width`. If adding a word would exceed the `text_width`, it starts a new line. Finally, it joins the lines with newline characters and returns the wrapped string.
